importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was updated, marking the 21st day of the federal government shutdown, and indicating the potential for surpassing the previous record of 35 days set during the first Trump administration.

The open enrollment deadline for Obamacare plans, which is critical because the expiration of enhanced subsidies could lead to premium hikes of up to double, potentially shifting public opinion and influencing whether Democrats back down or continue the standoff.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-day period from October 21 to November 1 is crucial as it encompasses the current shutdown and the impending open enrollment deadline, during which policy impacts and public opinion may shift significantly.

keyTakeAways: The federal government shutdown is now the second-longest in U.S. history, with 21 days passed and a potential record of 35 days looming if it continues into early November.
Democrats are demanding an extension of enhanced Obamacare subsidies, a policy that is widely supported by the public—72% of Americans and 51% of Republicans want it continued.
Despite this public support, Democrats are still winning the blame game in public opinion polls, with Americans blaming Republicans more than Democrats by 7 to 17 points in recent polling.
Historically, the side that makes extraneous policy demands (like Republicans in 1995–96 and 2018–19) has lost politically, but now Democrats' popular policy demand is reversing that dynamic.

The looming cost of premium hikes due to subsidy lapses—potentially doubling premiums—may pressure Democrats to back down on November 1, but also gives them leverage by making Republicans appear responsible for policy consequences.
If Republicans fear being blamed for higher healthcare costs, they may be incentivized to negotiate, creating a strategic opening for Democrats.
A key challenge is whether Democrats' base, which has criticized party leaders for lack of resolve, will accept a retreat when the party appears to have won the policy battle.
This shutdown differs from past ones because of the popularity of the policy demand and the public's perception of blame shifting to Republicans, which is not typical in previous shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Blake
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the author of the analysis piece, providing expert commentary on the political dynamics of the shutdown and public opinion trends.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the blame game, claiming Democrats are damaging their poll numbers and accusing them of wrongdoing in the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Marjorie Taylor Greene
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is cited as warning Republicans about the political consequences of the shutdown and the premium hikes it could trigger.

namedEntities.name: Reuters-Ipsos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Conducted key public opinion polls showing that Americans blame Republicans more than Democrats during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNBC
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Conducted a poll indicating that Americans blamed Trump and Republicans over Democrats by 53% to 37%.

namedEntities.name: KFF
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided data on how subsidy lapses could cause health insurance premiums to double in many cases.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare subsidies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central policy demand from Democrats, which is popular with the public and could influence political outcomes if extended or not.

namedEntities.name: Open enrollment for Obamacare
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The November 1 deadline for open enrollment is a pivotal moment that could shift public perception and policy decisions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The federal government shutdown is now in its 21st day, potentially setting a new record of 35 days, the longest in history. While historically the side making extraneous policy demands loses politically, Democrats are currently winning the blame game in public opinion, with Americans blaming Republicans more than Democrats by wide margins. This shift is due to the popularity of Democrats' demand to extend Obamacare subsidies—supported by 72% of Americans and 51% of Republicans—unlike previous shutdowns where GOP demands (like building a border wall) were unpopular. The looming impact of doubling health insurance premiums on November 1 could pressure Democrats to back down, yet the potential political gain from forcing Republicans to own policy consequences presents a strategic opportunity. This dynamic makes the current shutdown more complex than past ones, as Democrats may have a path to political victory despite the prolonged standoff, especially if Republicans fear backlash over rising premiums.
title: Could Democrats win the shutdown standoff? They’re still winning the blame game
